text: welcome to the eighth wonder of the
world this is the first tunnel under a
river anywhere in the world this dark
underground passage is the birthplace of
the tube system
it's the Thames tunnel which runs
between rather high than whopping and it
was designed and engineered by Mark
Brunell and his son Isambard it opened
in 1843 with the screams of excitement
and delight of 50,000 visitors built
originally for horse and carts the great
tunnel was to be an alternative to the
already overcrowded river Thames but
access to the tunnel was too difficult
for anything other than pedestrians so
it soon became more than just a means of
getting from A to B this is the world's
first underwater banquet hall the
world's first underwater shopping arcade
and the world's first underwater
fairground savvy businessmen and women
caught on to the fact they could have a
steady stream of customers and they used
the tunnel structure to their advantage
these archways were shops selling
hundreds of items to people walking
north and south what they bought were
trophies
after all you needed proof that you'd
ventured beneath the River Thames the
tunnel was a great feat of Engineering
no one believed it could be made it was
the first shield driven tunnel
construction in the world but the
process was a risky one Brunel came up
with the idea of a tunneling shield but
it had workers in little cells of about
21 feet by 6 feet and they they would do
to our shift and they'd have to come off
because the air and the gas was too so
much they were almost collapsing the
tunnel is now used by London Overground
trains carrying over a million
passengers every day a structure that
people once thought impossible has left
a very important legacy Charlotte Franks
BBC London News
